case_vignette: a 40-year-old female complains about squamous papules on her scalp for 10 years. these lesions responded to topical corticosteroids but recurs when the treatment is stopped. she denies any systemic symptoms. physical exam reveals erythematous scaly papules with signs of atrophy and scarring, as well as cicatricial alopecia. skin biopsy shows lichenoid interface dermatitis with hyperkeratosis and follicular plugging.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've had scaly, red bumps on my scalp for 10 years that keep coming back whenever I stop my cream treatment.
What type of cream have you been using to treat the condition?
I've been using a topical corticosteroid cream.
Does the condition ever spread beyond your scalp, such as to your face or body?
No, the condition has not spread beyond my scalp.
Do the symptoms worsen with stress or changes in the weather?
I haven't noticed any changes with stress or weather.
Have you ever been diagnosed by a healthcare professional with a specific condition for these symptoms?
No, I haven't been given a specific diagnosis by a healthcare professional.
Do any of your family members have similar symptoms or skin conditions?
No, my family members don't have similar symptoms or skin conditions.
Final Diagnosis: Psoriasis
